body:
Comment 3: 
If an interface value is non-nil, it means it has some kind of underlying type. It
doesn't matter what the underlying value is, whether it's nil, zero, or "donkey" it's
still a value, and therefore a non-nil interface value.

If you want a nil interface value, pass a nil interface value. Don't put something else
in there and expect it to be nil.

http://golang.org/doc/faq#nil_error
